thread.title: Mass prayer demo against Ahok ahead of Jakarta vote
thread.title_full: Mass prayer demo against Ahok ahead of Jakarta vote

title: Mass prayer demo against Ahok ahead of Jakarta vote
text:
News Indonesia Mass prayer demo against Ahok ahead of Jakarta vote Tens of thousands of people gather in Indonesia's capital urging voters to back Muslim candidates in upcoming elections. 11 Feb 2017 05:58 GMT Asia Pacific , Indonesia , Politics Ahok is running for re-election against two Muslim candidates[Reuters/Tatan Syuflana] 
Tens of thousands of Indonesians have gathered for mass prayers at Jakarta's national mosque, where religious leaders urged them to back a Muslim candidate in next week's vote to select the capital's governor. 
Organisers decided to hold Saturday's gathering at Istiqlal Mosque after police banned a planned street rally by those opposing incumbent Governor Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, who is accused of insulting the Quran. Ahok: Indonesia's religious tolerance on trial? - Talk to Al Jazeera 
An ethnic Chinese Christian popularly known as "Ahok", Purnama is on trial for alleged blasphemy but remains a leading candidate in Wednesday's elections. 
He will come up against two Muslims, Agus Harimurtri Yudhoyono, the son of the former president Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, and former education minister Anies Baswedan , in a contest analysts say has shaped as a proxy fight ahead of a presidential election in 2019. 
"On February 15, we are happy to vote for a Muslim leader," one speaker, Maulana Kamal Yusuf, told the crowd. 
"Jakarta will be led by a Muslim leader who submits to the will of Allah," he added, urging voters to choose Yudhoyono or Baswedan. 
"Jakarta will be a religious city." The gathering in Jakarta drew tens of thousands of Muslims [AFP] 
Police officials estimated that up to 70,000 attended the gathering, with people overflowing from the mosque in the heart of Indonesia's capital into the surrounding streets. 
Al Jazeera's Step Vaessen, reporting from Jakarta, said that people were streaming into the capital from across the country. 
"The other two Muslim candidates were also seen at the mass prayer, despite a police warning that this ... should be non-political - but people are carrying a lot political slogans here at the rally," she said. 
"This election is not about Jakarta; it has become a national topic. It's about religion and it says a lot [about] Indonesia's ... future." 
With many dressed in white shirts, the demonstrators arrived at the mosque in the early hours [AFP] 
Jakarta's governor is accused of saying his opponents had used a verse from the Quran to deceive voters and prevent him from winning another term during a meeting with residents in the city. 
Protests against him drew hundreds of thousands to Jakarta's streets in November and December and shook the government of President Joko "Jokowi" Widodo. 
If none of the contenders gets more than 50 percent of votes, a run-off election between the top-polling candidates would be held in April. 
Indonesia is the world's most populous Muslim nation but recognises several faiths and has a large Christian minority.
